poll_list.title: Ratification Poll for Legal And Commercial Risk Domain Work on Greenlit Collateral BlockTower Credit - RWA Arranger SPF (MIP55c3-SP9) - October 10, 2022

discourse_list.title: MIP55c3-SP9: Legal and Commercial Risk Domain Work on Greenlit Collateral BlockTower Credit (RWA Arranger) SPF

content.content: MIP55c3-SP9: Legal & Risk Domain Work on Greenlit Collateral BlockTower Credit (RWA Arranger)  Preamble MIP55c3-SP9: Legal & Commercial Risk Domain Work on Greenlit Collateral BlockTower Credit (RWA Arranger) Author(s): @Aes Contributors: Tags: spf Status: Accepted Date Proposed: 2022-09-07 Date Ratified: 2022-10-24 Amount Requested: 258K DAI Recipient Address: 0x117786ad59BC2f13cf25B2359eAa521acB0aDCD9 Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip55c3-sp9-legal-and-commercial-risk-domain-work-on-greenlit-collateral-blocktower-credit-rwa-arranger-spf/17776 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmcV2pMZ   Sentence Summary This SPF requests 258K DAI to support onboarding BlockTower Credit as a RWA Arranger pursuant to the greenlight passing.  Paragraph Summary This SPF provides funding for underwriting and performing the legal work necessary to onboard BlockTower Credit, to be completed by @christiancdpetersen and @teej.  Motivation BlockTower was recently greenlight and voted to be prioritized for onboarding. @christiancdpetersen and @teej have agreed to perform the domain work to facilitate onboarding, on a contract basis. SFCU will provide funding to the contracted individuals so the onboarding process can commence until the SPF is approved, at which point SF will be reimbursed and the remaining funds for the contracted individuals will be dispersed as the remaining work is completed.  Special Purpose Fund Name Legal & RWF Work on BlockTower Credit (RWA Arranger)  Special Purpose Fund Scope & Work Credentials  The scope of work will be to conduct a commercial risk assessment and legal review including, among other things:  Review of the legal structures Review of the resolution, wordings and workflow. Review of the agreement between entities and service providers. Writeup of a Legal Structure and Governance Appropriateness Verification. Other open legal review questions identified along the way. Commercial risk analysis: including but not limited to sponsor or arranger risk, credit risk, concentration risk, servicing risk, etc. Review of the commercial structure: flow of funds, leverage profile, credit enhancement, servicing mechanics, scaling/ramp-up/utilization structure, reps/warranties/covenants   Analysis of concentration risk, including but not limited to single-borrower, jurisdictional, sector, and asset type All-in recommendation: risks vs. opportunities, mitigants to risk vectors, bottom line recommendation to Maker community. The legal risk deliverable will be a Legal Structure and Governance Appropriateness Verification to be ratified by TBD The commercial risk deliverable will be a Commercial Risk Evaluation Once the deliverables are complete and the onboarding has reached the add new vault poll stage, 30K DAI will be paid to each of @christiancdpetersen and @teej   @christiancdpetersen and @teej know Maker and it’s Governance processes and are well-suited to perform the task of onboarding BlockTower Credit.   Funding Breakdown  Funding will be done in a lump sum upon Governance Approval of the SPF. DAI amounts assume three months to complete the requisite legal review and risk assessment and will be paid out pro-rata if the project is completed ahead of schedule. Excess funds will be held in the multi-sig until the work is complete. Unspent funds will be returned to the Surplus Buffer.       Dai     Legal review of BlockTower Credit 105K DAI   Risk assessment of BlockTower Credit 90K DAI   Customer Meetings 3K DAI   Due at Completion 60K DAI   Total 258K DAI     Special Purpose Fund Details Official Contact or Group Name: Legal & RWF Work on BlockTower Credit (RWA Arranger) Team Contact Email/Handle: @Aes Date Added: 2022-09-07 Total Amount: 258K In Dai. Wallet Address: 0x117786ad59BC2f13cf25B2359eAa521acB0aDCD9 Comptroller signers: @Aes, @prose11
content.GPT-summary: The post is a proposal for funding to support the onboarding of BlockTower Credit as a RWA Arranger. The proposal outlines the scope of work, funding breakdown, and deliverables. The author explains the proposal in detail, while also inviting constructive criticism and auditing/reviewing of the proposal by third parties.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: This is a summary of the contents of this subproposal and its impact, from GovAlpha’s perspective:  This is a valid subproposal to add a SPF, as defined in MIP55: Special Purpose Fund. This SPF aims to fund the necessary legal work to onboard BlockTower Credit as a RWA Arranger. This work will be completed by @christiancdpetersen and @teej. The proposal requests 258,000 DAI. As per MIP55c3, it is eligible to enter the Monthly Governance Cycle after having fulfilled its four-week Feedback Period and its one-week Frozen Period. If this subproposal is ratified, 258,000 DAI will be transferred to the specified MIP47-compliant multisig wallet through the earliest executive vote. This proposal has been assigned High-Impact based on the methodology listed here.  Disclaimer: These summaries are intended to be a guide and not a source of truth. You remain responsible for any actions you take on the grounds of this information. Please note the date when the summary was last updated to judge accuracy.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
None of the topics listed match
None of the topics listed match

content.content: @Aes and @prose11, please confirm that you agree to be a comptroller for this SPF.
Confirmed.

Aes:  Success onboarding as defined by an executive vote approving BlockTower Credit (RWA Arranger) MIP6 onboarding will result in a bonus of 30K DAI to each of @christiancdpetersen and @teej   Would you consider making this a flat fee to these contributors? That would avoid them losing money by highlighting major risks that could derail or delay closing of a deal.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: @GFXlabs - Fully understand the stated concern. We structured the proposal as such to reward a successful execution of the transaction. In doing so, we recognized the hypothetical concern of “cutting corners” to achieve the success bonus. We sought to address this concern by having the success bonus be tied to the affirmative MKR approval of the transaction via an executive vote. The success bonus is not guaranteed. Both @teej and I are fully on-board to engage with Maker independent of being formal contributors to a core unit. Given such, it seemed a reasonable ask for a success bonus tied to an affirmative approval by the MKR token holders.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: I don’t understand – isn’t a “success bonus” by definition tied to an executive vote? The issue is that packaging a reward with a specific outcome – whether a yes or a no – creates hazard.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: I am not entirely sure I understand the point being made in the 1st sentence, but you could tie a success bonus to any trigger. We assume that MKR token holders can always vote against the formal onboarding - that is in their discretion. If the vote is No, then there is not a success bonus. It seems that, by definition, most bonuses are “tied to a specific outcome” - particularly in the case of a success bonus. In the corporate context, KPIs (corporate and individual) are often the triggers for an employee’s bonus. Corporate officers get paid bonuses based on specific corporate outcomes. Independent consultants may be incentivized through a success bonus. How are any of the above conceptually different?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: The bonus should be tied to making the right call, not to recommending yes. If you interpret a “yes” vote as success, you implicitly interpret a “no” vote as failure. Which is a huge issue: a failure is a misguided vote, whether it’s a yes or a no. Honestly this seems so fundamental that I think I may be misunderstanding something. How can it be a good idea to make an evaluator more likely to get compensated if they give one answer rather than the other?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: swakya:  How can it be a good idea to make an evaluator more likely to get compensated if they give one answer rather than the other?   That is a fair observation. In response, I have always viewed my role within Maker as being more than an “evaluator” (notwithstanding inaccurate perceptions of entanglement and gate-keeping). I think if you see the work that @teej and I perform in structuring a transaction for the benefit of Maker token holders, it is simply more than “evaluation”. If it was merely an “evaluation”, we would not be as involved in providing guidance on commercial, legal and other points. While some may not like the term, we are in effect “negotiating” . . . otherwise MIP6 applicants will be encouraged to submit a take-or-leave it proposal. There is substantial behind the scenes work to improve the bare-bones offering that is typically a MIP6. We are probably no different than any deal team that has to report to a higher body. And not to unnecessarily re-hash raise an old issue, but the purpose of LOVE was to in effect monitor the deal team. But I agree with you, if the role is simply “evaluation”, then there is not any merit in a bonus.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: Hi all. This is not my deal so I can’t comment on the particulars. What I will comment on is an approach I would like to see for clarity sake. RWA deals are complex and involve a variety of parties. In the past, we’ve mixed some roles meaning, multiple people doing related tasks where in many environments, we would have separated the work. I think everyone’s intention is honorable and as we move more to a metadao structure, we’re having to work with ambiguity and a bias towards action. What I would suggest is to list the roles/responsibilities to what Mark has identified in the scope. Let’s be clear on who is doing what then have the discussion. I think a key issue is the tension between deal execution and providing risk/legal opinions. If we need to separate this, let’s do it and move on so we can focus on what is important…onboarding collateral to generate profits. Maybe it’s as simple as ensuring @christiancdpetersen is paid a normal fee and @teej gets a bonus for getting the deal over the line. What I think we need to prepare for as a community is the reality of a protector metadao. I’ve had to spend more time than I would have liked on this over the past week. From my learnings, the protectors are going to assume the risk for doing deals. Today, we don’t have the structure (incentive/disincentive) setup so the protector feels the reward/pain but we need to prepare for this reality. In the near future, it would be common to have the facilitator, arranger, legal, executors, etc. all working closely together to move deals through the system. For now, the community might feel better to separate these functions. Let’s just be aligned on who is doing what and move forward.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Aes:  Wallet Address: 0xf737C76D2B358619f7ef696cf3F94548fEcec379   And looks like we’ll need to update this

I think we need evaluation, notwithstanding the failure to onboard LOVE. I would be more comfortable with you taking a flat 30k fee. @aes, can we change the proposal to add a 30k line item for “Evaluation fee” and reduce the success fee to 30k? Also, perhaps not for this proposal, but in future proposals, we should consider an escrow period for the success fee.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Can i request for how the process of “Request for proposals” (RYP or tender process) being done? or is it to just find a consultant and use them without any assessment performed? Can we justify how the success fee of 30k derived? plucked from the sky or market rate etc? if an independent assessor is cheaper and why not?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: The fact that you hold a kind of dual role for now does not preclude you from avoiding bad incentives nor from giving ammo to any future criticism of Maker’s decision on an RWA deal. I think the proposal has the same chances of passing if the $30k is independent of the outcome. Maybe you think that’s not the case? Otherwise I’m not sure why you would maintain that structure which leaves open the possibility of bad incentives & bad appearances.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Updated the OP after aligning with the team and BlockTower on a timeline. Total funding requested is 258K DAI - 198K for three months of contracted work and an additional 60K once the work is completed and goes to the add new vault poll stage (regardless of vote outcome). SFCU will provide partial funding to the contracted individuals so we can commence onboarding work until the SPF is approved.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Hey man thanks for the breakdown and for providing the total funding. Question? Are the amounts of 105K DAI for Legal Review and 90K DAI for the Risk Assessment include outsourcing some of the work to 3rd parties? Or is this a one-man solo show interpreting the Risk, plus North Lake Legal doing all the legal reviews? It would be nice to have other human eyes in particularly, the Risk Assessment. Also, can MKR token owners get a guaranteed delivery of services within the 3-month period, and an extension of work without being charged if there are delays in work/reviews not being delivered, Force Majeure unforeseen events, or delays in the MakerDAO Governance process. I can easily see the clustering into an Arranger by BlockTower an event that might go beyond 90-days. Thanks in advance. Cc: @christiancdpetersen @teej
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: flipflopflapdelegate:  Or is this a one-man solo show interpreting the Risk, plus North Lake Legal doing all the legal reviews? It would be nice to have other human eyes in particularly, the Risk Assessment.   BlockTower had previously agreed, subject to a defined scope of work, to cover any additional external legal review required by Maker. In this regard, I have contacted a firm to run conflicts (conflicts is cleared), I have not yet asked for a quote as the scope of work is still being defined.     flipflopflapdelegate:  Also, can MKR token owners get a guaranteed delivery of services within the 3-month period, and an extension of work without being charged if there are delays in work/reviews not being delivered, Force Majeure unforeseen events, or delays in the MakerDAO Governance process.   A question of “force majeure” to a energy lawyer!  There is nothing a projects lawyer likes to discuss more than force majeure! All joking aside - the 3 month estimate is the result of our most recent experience with HVB. Having said that, BlockTower did want to speed things up (which @teej and I fully support), so we are aiming for less than 3 months. @teej and I will prepare a proposed execution GANTT chart for the community this week as part of our proposed weekly updates. At the end of the day, as we work for the benefit of the Maker token holders, I think that a simple request to “stop work” will be respected - particularly if there are outside events occurring that give cause for concern on extended timing.     flipflopflapdelegate:  I can easily see the clustering into an Arranger by BlockTower an event that might go beyond 90-days.   An interesting observation - are you referring to “clustering” with a MetaDAO? The proposed 3 month time schedule will be independent of any “clustering” … there is not enough certainty (today) on how exactly to “cluster” a transaction with the still evolving MetaDAO concept. Having said that, we are evaluating how we might provide some contractual guidance/flexibility on a “clustering” with a MetaDAO. Frankly, for any assets on-boarded before the formal launch of the MetaDAO, this will be an issue to consider. There may be a handful of commercial and financial issues to consider when the MetaDAO assumes an existing asset from Maker. But I will not speculate here and I certainly can’t identify them at present.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: Aes:  MIP55c3-SP9: Legal & Risk Domain Work on Greenlit Collateral BlockTower Credit (RWA Arranger)   Holy, thats a lot of DAI to do KYC. Please share service tender process and service agreement. Can anyone in the US confirm this is a fair amount?

content.content: Reminder that this proposal will enter its Frozen Period on Wednesday, September 28 at 23:59 UTC. Substantive modifications beyond that date will render the proposal ineligible for the upcoming Governance Cycle / reset its Frozen Period, as the case may be.
@Aes please confirm if you are aiming to formally submit this SP for the October Cycle by Wednesday. Let us know if you have any questions. Thank you!
Formally submitting - thanks!

fumoffuXx:  Holy, thats a lot of DAI to do KYC. Please share service tender process and service agreement. Can anyone in the US confirm this is a fair amount?   If you’re referring to the 105k DAI here  then, ya maybe it’s a bit high, but you get what you pay for.      Aes:      Legal review of BlockTower Credit 105K DAI     Risk assessment of BlockTower Credit 90K DAI   Customer Meetings 3K DAI   Due at Completion 60K DAI   Total 258K DAI       Depending on the complexity of the entity owner, the corporate structure and jurisdiction, to do it well could require a lot of manual work. KYB is notoriously error prone and manual still. I think this is an area where you don’t want to necessarily pinch pennies because it’s important to be accurate when determining counter-party risk appropriately. Something that could potentially be standardized and improved upon with future deals. Specifically:  Methods for determination; 3rd parties/tools used for determination; and Order of ops/playbook (ie. CU member does first pass, then have independent 3rd party verify)  Nothing about the current proposal seems out of line. Excited to see how this progresses!
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
